title: Area Formula for a Triangle
text: The area formula for a triangle is $$\frac{1}{2} bh$$, where $$b$$ is the base and $$h$$ is the height.

title: Drawing a Diagram
text: First draw, a diagram. By graphing f(x) and the line perpendicular to it, we can tell that the height of the triangle is equal to the y-coordinate of the intersection between f(x) and the perpendicular line. We can also see that the horizontal base of the triangle is the distance from $$(0,0)$$ to the point where f(x) intersects the $$x$$ axis.

title: Figuring Out the Equation of the Perpendicular Line
text: The first step is to figure out the equation of the perpendicular line. Because it is perpendicular to $$f(x)=9-\frac{6}{7} x$$, we know that its slope is equal to the opposite reciprocal of the slope of f(x).

title: Figuring Out the Slope of the Relevant Line

title: Interpreting the Intersection Between f(x) and its Reciprocal
text: Through graphing, we know that the y-coordinate of the intersection is the height of the triangle, and the intersection has coordinates $$(\frac{85}{42},\frac{356}{49})$$. Thus, the height of the triangle is $$\frac{356}{49}$$.

title: Finding the Intersection of f(x) with the $$x$$ axis
text: When $$y=0$$, f(x) intersects the $$x$$ axis. Plug in $$y=0$$ to the equation for f(x). What is $$x$$ equal to when $$y=0$$?

title: Base of the Triangle
text: The base of the triangle is equal to the x-coordinate of the intersection between f(x) and the $$x$$ axis.
speech: The base of the triangle is equal to the x-coordinate of the intersection between f(x) and the  x  axis.
